Detailed Description

Memory pools, also known as fixed-size block allocation, enable dynamic memory allocation similar to malloc or C++'s operator new. However, these implementations are prone to fragmentation due to variable block sizes and are therefore not recommended for use in real-time systems where performance is critical. To address this issue, a more efficient approach is to preallocate a fixed number of memory blocks of the same size, which is known as a memory pool. During runtime, the application can allocate, access, and free blocks represented by handles, resulting in improved performance.

Definition in file itempool.h.
